title: 4 Simple Ways to View Cookies in a Web Browser

steps.title: Open Google Chrome and click ⋮.
steps.content: Open Google Chrome and click ⋮ . This icon is in the top-right corner of the Chrome window. A drop-down menu will open.

steps.title: Click Settings.
steps.content: Click Settings . It's toward the bottom of the drop-down menu. A new window will open.

steps.title: Click Privacy and security.
steps.content: Click Privacy and security . This will be on the left panel, underneath Autofill and passwords . [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click Third-party cookies.
steps.content: Click Third-party cookies . It's under the "Privacy and security" header and has an icon of a cookie.

steps.title: Click See all site data and permissions.
steps.content: Click See all site data and permissions . You may need to scroll down to find this option. [2] X Research source The All sites page will open.

steps.title: View your cookies.
steps.content: View your cookies. You'll see a list of visited websites. [3] X Research source Click the drop-down menu for Sort by and select: Most visited, Data stored, or Name. You can also use the search bar in the top-right corner to search for specific websites. Click the arrow next to each website to expand its details. You can adjust permission for each cookie here. To delete a cookie , select a website and click the trash can. You can also delete Google Chrome history .

steps.title: Open Safari and click Safari.
steps.content: Open Safari and click Safari . This will be in the top toolbar, next to the Apple logo.

steps.title: Click Settings.
steps.content: Click Settings . A new window will open. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Click Privacy.
steps.content: Click Privacy . This is the top tab between Security and Websites . [5] X Research source

steps.title: Click Manage Website Data….
steps.content: Click Manage Website Data… . You can find this below Cookies and website data . [6] X Research source

steps.title: View your cookies.
steps.content: View your cookies. You'll see a list of visited websites. Use the search bar in the top-right to find specific websites, or scroll up and down. To delete a cookie, select the website and click Remove . [7] X Research source You can also click Remove All to clear all cookies. When you're finished, click Done .

steps.title: Open Microsoft Edge and click ••• .
steps.content: Open Microsoft Edge and click ••• . This will be in the top-right corner. A pop-up menu will open.

steps.title: Click Settings.
steps.content: Click Settings . You can find this towards the bottom of the menu. [8] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source A new window will open.

steps.title: Click Cookies and site permissions.
steps.content: Click Cookies and site permissions . This will be on the left panel, underneath Share, copy and paste . [9] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Manage cookies.
steps.content: Click Manage cookies . You can find this at the very top of the page. You'll be redirected to a new page. [10] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: View your cookies.
steps.content: View your cookies. You'll see a list of visited websites. Click Sort by and select: Name, Most cookies, Most data, or Last modified. You can also click Filter by and select: All, First party, or Third party. To delete individual cookies, select the website, then click the trashcan icon. You can also click Remove all or Remove third-party cookies at the top-right.

steps.title: Open Mozilla Firefox and click ☰.
steps.content: Open Mozilla Firefox and click ☰ . This icon is in the top-right corner of the browser window.

steps.title: Click Settings.
steps.content: Click Settings . You can find this at the bottom, above More tools . A new window will open.

steps.title: Click Privacy & Security.
steps.content: Click Privacy & Security . This will be on the left panel, underneath Search .

steps.title: Click Manage Data….
steps.content: Click Manage Data… . This is underneath the Cookies and Site Data header. You may need to scroll down. A pop-up window will open.

steps.title: View your cookies.
steps.content: View your cookies. Click each title to sort by: Site, Cookies, Storage, and Last used. Type into the search bar to find specific websites. To remove a cookie, select the website and click Remove Selected . [11] X Research source To remove all cookies, click Remove All . When you're finished, click Save Changes in the bottom-right corner.

steps.title: Navigate to a website you want to view the cookies for.
steps.content: Navigate to a website you want to view the cookies for. If you need to view in-depth information about the cookies that are saved for a particular site, follow these steps. These steps work for Chrome, Firefox, and Safari.

steps.title: Right-click or control-click on the web page and choose Inspect Element.
steps.content: Right-click or control-click on the web page and choose Inspect Element . The option may also say Inspect depending on the browser you're using. This will pull up a pane on the side or bottom of your browser window.

steps.title: Navigate to the Storage tab.
steps.content: Navigate to the Storage tab. In Chrome, you'll want to click Application instead.

steps.title: Look at the cookies in the sidebar.
steps.content: Look at the cookies in the sidebar. Under the "Cookies" header in the sidebar, you'll see all of the cookies the current web page has saved. You may need to expand the Cookies tab to see all of the cookies.
